stream_context.summary: Kaze implemented the AI and behavior for several new NPCs for a Wild West level, including a Dry Bones enemy and a 'Cow Boshi' character for a shootout minigame. The assets were created by his wife and collaborator, Zeina. Throughout the stream, he discussed his core game design philosophies, technical choices regarding performance, and his relationship with the broader Mario 64 modding community.

development_findings.summary: Kaze believes Mario 64 is a special candidate for hacking because its unique movement physics have not been replicated in sequels, unlike Mario Kart 64 which he feels was surpassed by its successors.
development_findings.quote: The problem with hacking a game like Mario Kart 64 is that Mario Kart double dash and Mario Kart Wii exists so there's two alternatives that are kind of just like superior games but Mario 64 there's something very unique about it and that is the physics the movement that no other game coming after it can replicate.

development_findings.summary: For the 'Cow Boshi' shootout minigame, Kaze is implementing dynamic difficulty scaling to ensure accessibility, acknowledging that reaction-time challenges can be impossible for some players or those with high-latency setups.
development_findings.quote: every consequent loss makes them wait slightly longer so we're gonna make it so that every time you lose the game gets a little bit easier just to make sure everyone can beat it because reaction time is one of those fixed things

development_findings.summary: A common technique Kaze uses to make movement look natural is to programmatically scale the playback speed of an animation to match the character's actual movement speed.
development_findings.quote: I usually scale animations with the walking speed it is the easiest thing to make good-looking I think

development_findings.summary: Kaze clarifies that asset quality is limited by the N64's rendering performance, not storage space. Therefore, solutions like the 64DD that offer more storage wouldn't allow for significantly higher quality assets.
development_findings.quote: The assets are not low quality because we have less storage space they are low quality because the n64 struggles to render anything high quality than this so more space doesn't help.

development_findings.summary: Kaze meticulously recreates enemy behaviors from other games, such as the Dry Bones's crumble-and-reassemble animation from New Super Mario Bros., by studying video footage frame-by-frame.

Kaze consciously maintains his own fork of the decompilation project, separate from larger community projects like Heka-64, because he disagrees with some of their changes and believes his version is more optimized.
development_findings.quote: I wouldn't want to work off heka even if I didn't have this repo because they make so many random changes to mario 64 that I just don't want in the repo.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is working on a Wild West-themed level (Course 12) featuring a saloon, and a retro-themed sub-area for Course 14 based on Kalimari Desert from Mario Kart 64.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses strong disdain for streamers who foster parasocial relationships by sharing mundane personal details, viewing it as narcissistic.
context_findings.quote: talking what you ate feels so incredibly narcissistic to me. it's like who gives a shit you think you're that special that anyone cares what you ate the fuck and how parasocial do you have to be to actually care

context_findings.summary: Kaze's core motivation is experimentation and personal growth, not just creating content that will be popular. He is driven by the desire to see his own ideas realized and to learn from the process.
context_findings.quote: I made things because I wanted to see them it's literally it... I want to make something I always make it with the idea like I'm gonna learn from this and become even better.

context_findings.summary: Kaze values games that provide intrinsic motivation (fun for its own sake) over extrinsic motivation (doing tasks for a reward), citing Tears of the Kingdom as a prime example and Pokemon as the opposite.
context_findings.quote: if you play a game like Tears of the Kingdom and you build a machine it's a fucking waste of your time practically speaking but it's fun that's pure intrinsic motivation.

context_findings.summary: Kaze shows pride and a sense of humor about his very specific skillset in recreating nuanced enemy behaviors from other Nintendo games.
context_findings.quote: I'm probably the world champion of matching the big dry bones behavior news for Mario Bros games

context_findings.summary: Kaze reveals that his on-stream frustration is often triggered by what he perceives as inane questions, as it puts him in a position where he feels he can't respond harshly without being an 'asshole', causing him internal conflict.
context_findings.quote: there's one person in chat always asking me stupid questions it's like my number one thing that I cannot deal with if there's someone who earnestly has like a thing that he wants or like a question to ask but it's just because I can't even like be mean to that and like feel righteous about it you know what I mean I would be like an asshole so I just get upset

biobak.summary: Kaze views Biobak as a technical resource, asking him for a hotkey reminder for his 3D software, though Biobak didn't have the answer.
Kaze privately sent Biobak a link to a secret collaboration level to get his opinion, trusting his artistic judgment.

zeina.summary: Zeina created the animations for the Dry Bones enemy, which Kaze was very impressed with upon implementation.
zeina.quote: Zayna, the Dry Bones look really, really good in-game. You will love them.

zeina.summary: Zeina created the model for a piano-playing NPC and the 'Cow Boshi' character, including his animations for a shootout minigame.
The professional and personal relationship is intertwined; Kaze casually asks Zeina for his credit card on stream to purchase a new piece of development hardware.
zeina.quote: You still have my credit card, right, Zeina? I'll need that to buy the thing.

zeina.summary: There is a collaborative workflow where Kaze preps a model (e.g., fixing UVs, optimizing) and sends it back to Zeina for her to animate.

key_stories.title: Recreating the Modern Dry Bones
key_stories.summary: To bring a Dry Bones enemy to life, Kaze combined animations from Zeina with meticulous, self-taught programming. He reverse-engineered its modern behavior from video footage to create a complex and polished enemy that felt authentic.
key_stories.challenge: A new Dry Bones enemy needed to be implemented with behavior that was faithful to its appearances in modern Mario games, which is complex for the N64 engine.
key_stories.process: Kaze integrated animations from Zeina, coded the chase and line-of-sight logic, scaled animation speed to movement, and studied video of New Super Mario Bros. frame-by-frame to perfectly replicate the enemy's reaction to being jumped on.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully implemented a polished Dry Bones enemy with custom AI, sound effects, and a frame-perfect crumble-and-reassemble mechanic, praising the animations provided by Zeina.
key_stories.key_quote: Man, I'm good at such a specific thing I'm probably the world champion of matching the big dry bones behavior news for Mario Bros games.

key_stories.title: The Philosophy of Intrinsic Motivation
key_stories.summary: Kaze laid out his entire game design philosophy, explaining that he is driven by intrinsic motivation—the joy of creation and learning—rather than chasing popularity. He values experimentation and personal growth above all, which explains his eclectic project history.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze needed to explain his core motivation for game development and why he sometimes creates niche or experimental content.
key_stories.process: In response to chat, Kaze contrasted games that offer intrinsic rewards (fun for its own sake, like building in TotK) with those offering extrinsic rewards (like a job). He placed his own work in the former category, citing past projects like the 'bathroom level' as experiments he did for himself.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze articulated a clear design philosophy centered on intrinsic motivation, experimentation, and personal growth, explaining that his goal isn't always to make something popular but to explore concepts and improve his skills.
key_stories.key_quote: I made things because I wanted to see them it's literally it... I always make it with the idea like I'm gonna learn from this and become even better.

key_stories.title: Designing an Accessible Duel
key_stories.summary: When creating a shootout minigame, Kaze focused not just on the theme and action but also on accessibility. He designed a dynamic difficulty system to accommodate players with slower reaction times, demonstrating a thoughtful approach to user experience even in a small side activity.
key_stories.challenge: Designing an engaging and accessible shootout minigame with the new 'Cow Boshi' character.
key_stories.process: Kaze brainstormed a quick-draw duel concept. He wrote dialogue to establish the character's 'angsty teen' personality, designed a reaction-based mechanic, and crucially, decided to add an accessibility feature where the AI gets easier after each loss. He then spent time perfecting the camera setup for the scene.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze designed and began implementing a complete minigame sequence, including cowboy-themed dialogue, a dynamic difficulty system to ensure fairness, and carefully planned cinematic camera work.
key_stories.key_quote: every consequent loss makes them wait slightly longer... just to make sure everyone can beat it because reaction time is one of those fixed things where some people are gonna be in able to do this on the first try or ever actually

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions he is working on a level for a collaboration with a creator named 'Aza' and that the level will be used in both projects to 'double cash in'. He did not show the level on stream.
questions: Who is Aza and what is the nature of this collaboration?
How does collaborating with other creators influence your design process?
What are the challenges or benefits of designing a level that needs to fit into two different projects?

open_questions.context: Kaze expresses frustration with the Everdrive flashcart, saying 'the X5 doesn't work for me.' He decides on stream to purchase a custom-made alternative called the 'summer cart' to improve his hardware testing workflow.
questions: What specific problems have you encountered with commercial flashcarts like the Everdrive?
How does using custom community-made hardware like the 'summer cart' change your development and testing process?
How important is it for you to test on original N64 hardware, and what insights does it give you that emulators can't?

open_questions.context: Kaze explains that he maintains his own branch of the Mario 64 decompilation and doesn't use community repos like 'hexam64' because he believes his is more optimized and he disagrees with some of their changes.
questions: Can you elaborate on the key technical or philosophical differences between your project's code base and Heka-64?
What are the pros and cons of this fractured development landscape within the decomp community?
How does it feel when your performance optimizations aren't ported back into the main community projects?

open_questions.context: Zeina is a primary contributor of character models and animations. Kaze is shown prepping one of her models (piano player) before sending it back to her for animation, indicating a back-and-forth workflow.
questions: (For Zeina) What is your creative process for designing new characters that fit into the world Kaze is building?
(For Kaze and Zeina) Can you describe your collaborative workflow? How do you give feedback to each other and iterate on assets?
How does your personal relationship as a married couple influence your professional collaboration on this project?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions a technical issue where 'new fpdx is still too slow' and that he needs to 'debug it another day with Sauraen.'
questions: Who is Sauraen and what is their role in the project or the wider community?
Can you explain in simple terms what 'fpdx' is and why it was causing performance problems?
How do you collaborate with other technical experts in the modding scene to solve complex coding challenges?
